text: Wɔ sukuu adwumadi kɔntɔnkrɔn mu no, Twi adwumadi yɛ nsɛm a wɔakyerɛw a wɔhwɛ adwumadi titirew baako so.
translation: In school composition practice, a Twi composition is a written piece that focuses on a single central theme.

source.document: ASANTE TWI COMPOSITION TWI VERSION.pdf

text: Wɔ Twi adwumadi mu no, adwumadi ahodoɔ abiɛsa na wɔkyerɛkyerɛ: adwumadi asɛm-nkaeɛ (narrative), adwumadi adwumadi-kɔntɔnkrɔn (descriptive), ne adwumadi (expository).
translation: In Twi composition, three types are taught: narrative, descriptive, and expository compositions.

source.document: ASANTE TWI COMPOSITION TWI VERSION.pdf

text: Adwumadi asɛm-nkaeɛ (narrative) yɛ adwumadi a ɔkyerɛwfoɔ ka ne ho asɛm anaa asɛm a esiiɛ wɔ ne abrabɔ mu wɔ bere a atwam mu.
translation: A narrative composition is one in which the writer recounts personal experiences or events that happened in the past.

source.document: ASANTE TWI COMPOSITION TWI VERSION.pdf

text: Adwumadi adwumadi-kɔntɔnkrɔn (descriptive) kɔntɔnkrɔn adeɛ, onipa, anaa baabi pɛpɛɛpɛ, na ɛkyerɛ ne su ne ne ho nsɛm.
translation: A descriptive composition describes an object, person, or place in detail, explaining its features.

source.document: ASANTE TWI COMPOSITION TWI VERSION.pdf

text: Adwumadi (expository) kɔntɔnkrɔn asɛm bi na ɛkyerɛ adwumadi adwumadi pɔtee bi ho asɛm.
translation: An expository composition explains a particular idea or topic clearly.

source.document: ASANTE TWI COMPOSITION TWI VERSION.pdf

text: Twi ano-akyɛdeɛ yɛ amammerɛ adwumadie a wɔde kasa anaa ano na ɛma amammerɛ ne abrabɔ ho nimdeɛ kɔ so wɔ abusua ne ɔman mu.
translation: Twi oral literature is a cultural practice transmitted through speech that preserves knowledge about culture and life within the family and society.

source.document: ASANTE TWI LITERATURE TWI VERSION.pdf

text: Mmebɔnekyerɛ (proverbs) ka Twi ano-akyɛdeɛ ho, na wɔde kɔkyerɛ nyansa, amammerɛ, ne abrabɔ mu mmara.
translation: Proverbs are part of Twi oral literature and are used to convey wisdom, culture, and moral rules of life.

source.document: ASANTE TWI LITERATURE TWI VERSION.pdf

text: Anansesɛm ka Twi ano-akyɛdeɛ ho, na wɔde kɔkyerɛ abrabɔ su ne nyansa wɔ asɛm-nkaeɛ mu.
translation: Ananse stories are part of Twi oral literature and are used to teach moral values and wisdom through storytelling.

source.document: ASANTE TWI LITERATURE TWI VERSION.pdf

text: Abosomdin yɛ din ahodoɔ a yɛde to mma a ɛkyerɛ abosom a wɔwɔ Ghana mmusuakuo mu.
translation: Deity names are names given to children that refer to the deities found within Ghanaian ethnic groups.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Mfasoɔ a ɛwɔ abosomdin so no bi ne sɛ, ɛboa ma onipa no nya ahoɔden, ahobammɔ, ne honhom mu tumi.
translation: One of the significances of deity names is that it helps the person obtain strength, protection, and spiritual power.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Bragoro yɛ ɔkwan a yɛfa so pagya mmabunu kɔ wɔn mpanin mfee so.
translation: Bragoro (Puberty Rites) is the process used to elevate youth into their adult years.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Ansa na wɔbɛgoro bra no, ɛsɛ sɛ wosusu nneɛma bi te sɛ onipa ko a ɔyɛ, ne mfeɛ a wadi, ne n'abrabɔ.
translation: Before puberty rites are performed, things such as the person's background, age, and character must be considered.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Wɔ Akuapem Twi mu no, yɛfrɛ Bible no 'Nkwa Asɛm'. Wɔ Asante Twi mu no, yɛtaa frɛ no 'Twere Kronkron'.
translation: In Akuapem Twi, the Bible is called 'Nkwa Asɛm' (Word of Life). In Asante Twi, it is often called 'Twere Kronkron' (Holy Scripture).

source.document: Twi-Akuapem-All-Bible.pdf & Twi-New-Revised-Asante-All-Bible.pdf

text: Wɔfrɛ Bible nhoma a ɛdi kan no '1 Mose' wɔ Akuapem Twi mu, nanso wɔ Asante Twi mu no, wɔfrɛ no 'Gyenesis'.
translation: The first book of the Bible is called '1 Mose' in Akuapem Twi, but 'Gyenesis' in Asante Twi.

source.document: Twi-Akuapem-All-Bible.pdf (p.2) & Twi-New-Revised-Asante-All-Bible.pdf (p.2)

text: Wɔ Asante Twi mu no, yɛtwerɛ 'Eksodos', nanso Akuapemfoɔ twerɛ no '2 Mose'.
translation: In Asante Twi, we write 'Eksodos', but the Akuapems write it as '2 Mose'.

source.document: Twi-Akuapem-All-Bible.pdf & Twi-New-Revised-Asante-All-Bible.pdf

text: Abosomdin yɛ din ahodoɔ a yɛde to mma de kyerɛ abosom a ɛda nnipa no ne obosom no ntam twaka no nti. Abosom no tumi ne n'adwumadi kyerɛ din a wɔde to onipa no ho.
translation: Deity names are names given to children that show the connection between the person and a deity. The deity's power and function determines the name given to the person.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Abosomdin abɔseɛ da nsɔ ɔsom ahodoɔ mu a ɛgyina wɔn a wɔto edin no gyidie ne wɔn amammerɛ so. Akanfoɔ nya wɔn abosomdin firii asuo ahodoɔ mu, Ewefoɔ de wɔn firii Yeʋe (Agradaa Nyame), na Dangmefoɔ de wɔn firii Ɔbɔadeɛ Nyame hɔ.
translation: The origins of deity names come from the religious and cultural beliefs of the people. Akan people derive theirs from river deities, Ewe people from Yeʋe (Thunder God), and Dangme people from the God of recreation.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Nnipa de to abosomdin de kyerɛ dwuma a ɔbosom no di anaa ne tumi. Bio nso, awarefoɔ a wɔnnya awoɔ a wɔkɔ abosom nkyɛn kɔpɛ mmoa, wɔhyɛ ɛbɔ na wɔde wɔn ba no to ɔbosom no de di wɔn bɔhyɛ no so.
translation: People give deity names to show the work or power of a deity. Also, when couples cannot have children, they go to deities seeking help by making vows and naming their children after the deities as fulfillment of those vows.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Abosomdintoɔ so mfasoɔ nyinaa: (1) Yɛde hyɛ wɔn nso - abosomdin boa ma yɛhunu ɔbosom pɔtee a onipa no som no ne beaeɛ a onipa no firii. (2) Ɛkyerɛ twaka a ɛda onipa no ne ɔbosom no ntam. (3) Abosomdintoɔ boa ma amammerɛ ne ɔsom ase tim. (4) Ɛda awofoɔ no gyidie a wɔwɔ wɔ ɔbosom no mu adi. (5) Abosomdintoɔ boa ma deɛ ɔkura abosomdin no nya ahoɔden, ahobammɔ ne honhom mu tumi.
translation: The significance of deity names includes: (1) Identification - shows which deity one worships and origin; (2) Connection - shows the link between the person and deity; (3) Cultural preservation - passed through generations; (4) Shows parental beliefs; (5) Grants strength, protection, and spiritual authority.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Bragorɔ (wɔ Asante Twi) anaa Bragoru (wɔ Akuapim Twi) yɛ Akanfoɔ amammerɛ bi a wɔyɛ de pagya mmabunu kɔ wɔn mpanin mfeɛ so. Ɛyɛ amammerɛ ne amanneɛ ɛkɔ wɔ abadintoɔ akyi a ɛpagya no firi mmɔfra mu kɔ mpanin mu.
translation: Bragoro (Asante) or Bragoru (Akuapim) is an Akan cultural practice used to transition youth into adulthood. It is a traditional custom marking the passage from childhood to maturity.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf & Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES akuapim twi version.pdf

text: Nsakraeɛ a ɛda adi wɔ mmaayewa nipadua mu: wɔn sisi akyi trɛ, wɔn aserɛ yɛ akɛseɛ, wɔn to yeyɛ akɛseɛ nkorowankorowa, wɔbu wɔn nsa a ɛdi kan, wɔn nufoɔ yeyɛ akɛseɛ, na nwi fu wɔ wɔn baa so ne wɔn mmɔtoam.
translation: Physical changes in girls include: wider pelvic area, larger thighs, rounded buttocks, first menstruation, breast development, and growth of hair in pubic area and armpit.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf
source.section: Nsakraeɛ a ɛda adi wɔ mmaayewa nipadua mu

text: Nsakraeɛ a ɛda adi wɔ mmarimaa nipadua mu: wɔn tadua ne wɔn hwoa yeyɛ akɛseɛ, nwi fu wɔ wɔn tadua so ne wɔn mmɔtoam, wɔn koko ne wɔn mmatire yeyɛ akɛseɛ, wɔn honam mu ntini nso mu yɛ den, wɔn ɛnne mu yɛ duru, wɔyɛ tenten, na wɔfu abɔgyesɛ.
translation: Physical changes in boys include: enlargement of penis and testicles, growth of hair in pubic areas and armpit, broader chest and shoulders, developed muscles, deepening of voice, increase in height, and growth of facial hair.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf
source.section: Nsakraeɛ a ɛda adi wɔ mmarimaa nipadua mu

text: Ansa na wɔbɛgoro bra no, awofoɔ hu nsakraeɛ bi wɔ wɔn mmammaa nipadua mu a, wɔhyɛ aseɛ yɛ ahoboa. Wɔyi mmaayewa no firii abusuakuo no mu kɔhyɛ baabi siesie wɔn ma bragorɔ dwumadie no. Abusuafo kɔbɔ mpanimfoɔ anaa Nsumankwaahene. Mmaa mpanimfoɔ de asakyima no hyɛ ɛdan mu kyerɛkyerɛ wɔn abrabɔ pa ne awarefoɔ asɛdeɛ.
translation: Before initiation, parents identify physical changes in their adolescent daughters and begin preparations. Girls are separated from family to prepare. Parents inform elders and spiritual leaders. Experienced women educate the initiates on acceptable female behavior and marriage readiness.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf
source.section: Ansa na wɔbɛgoro bra no mu dwumadie

text: Bragorɔ no ankasa mu no, ɔkɔmfoɔ no anaa ɔbaapanin no di dwuma ahodoɔ a ɛdidi soɔ yi: ɔgu nsa de srɛ ɔdɔ ne ahobammɔ firii nananom abosom hɔ. Wɔyɛ honhom mu amanneɛ bi de hwɛ sɛ mmayewa no mfaa ɔbarima da. Ɔkɔmfoɔ no yi mmaayewa no tiri ho nwi nyinaa. Wɔma asakyima no tena asesedwa anaa bɔnwoma so. Wɔde Akanfoɔ afadeɛ te sɛ kente, nhwenepa ne mponporanneɛ siesie wɔn ho.
translation: During initiation, the priest/priestess performs libation to invoke blessings and protection from deities. Spiritual testing is done to verify virginity. Girls' heads are shaved. They are enskinned on special stools. They are adorned in traditional Akan clothes like kente and beads.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Bragorɔ no akyi no, mmaayewa a wɔapagya wɔn kɔ wɔn mpanin mfeɛ so no ne wɔn abusuafoɔ ne wɔn nnamfonom kyinkyin kuro no mu kɔdeda ɔmanfoɔ no ase. Ɔmanfoɔ no de akyɛdeɛ ahodoɔ ma wɔn de bɔ wɔn abaso sɛ wɔafa bragorɔ dwumadie no mu asomdwoeɛ mu. Akyɛdeɛ ahodoɔ no mu bi ne sika, nhwenepa, ntoma, duku ne deɛ ɛkeka ho.
translation: After initiation, the new adults go around the community with family and friends to thank community members. The community gives gifts to celebrate the successful initiation, including money, beads, cloth, scarves, and more.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Ewe people call their girls' puberty rite Gbɔtowɔwɔ/Tugbewɔwɔ and boys' rite Tudedeasi. Krobo people call it Dipo. Fante people call it Bragor. Twi people call it Bragoro (Asante) or Bragoru (Akuapim). Akpafu call it Iseyi. Ga people call it Otofo/Otseŋtse for girls and Plamatsemɔ/Butrumwɔɔ/Deŋtuwoo for boys. Sissala call boys' rite Baala. Vagla call it Pellaa.
translation: Different ethnic groups have different names for their puberty rites, reflecting their unique cultural practices and traditions.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf

text: Bragorɔ so mfasoɔ bi: (1) Ɛpagya mmabunu kɔ mpanin mu. (2) Ɛma wɔnya nimdeɛ de bɔ wɔn bra. (3) Ɛde kyerɛ sɛ ɔbabunu bi aso awareɛ. (4) Ɛde siesie mmabunu wɔ honhom ne honam mu ma awareɛ. (5) Ɛde kyerɛkyerɛ mmabunu no subanpa ne abrabɔpa. (6) Ɛde kyerɛkyerɛ mmabunu no wɔn amammerɛ ne wɔn amanneɛ. (7) Ɛnam so de si mmabunu abrabɔ bɔne. (8) Ɛnam so ma abaayewa no nya dwetire de bɔ bra daakye.
translation: Significance of bragoro includes: (1) Marks transition to adulthood. (2) Provides knowledge for new status. (3) Shows readiness for marriage. (4) Prepares physically and spiritually. (5) Teaches good character. (6) Teaches cultural values. (7) Prevents immoral behavior. (8) Provides capital for girls' future.

source.document: Ghanaian-Languages_DEITY NAMES AND PUBERTY_INITIATION RITES asante twi version.pdf
